item.title: Learning Rust
item.description: One of my 2024 batch goals at Recurse is to learn Rust. How? work through three introductory Rust resources The Rust Book Rustlings Yet Another Rust Resource) implement a small project in Rust My solutions: msyvr/rusty msyvr/rustlings msyvr/yarry

item.title: *Git wizardry
item.description: Fringe Obscure but useful Git incantations The hard parts Git, detached HEAD - Flavio Copes Some standard Git workflows Adding the current commit to an earlier commit where… target commit = most recent commit: git commit --amend target commit < most recent commit: git commit --fixup=<commit hash> git rebase -i --autosquash main (alternately…) git commit --fixup :/<some-identifying-word-from-target-commit-message> git rebase -i --autosquash main

item.title: Recurse Center
item.description: “The retreat where curious programmers recharge and grow” I first joined the Recurse community in the fall of 2021, then returned for a second batch in the summer of 2024. Recurse brands itself as the equivalent of a writers’ retreat - but for software engineers. Recursers work at the edge of their abilities to become dramatically better programmers during their batch, then never-graduate and join the 2000+ alumni community. What do Recurses do during their batches?

item.title: README
item.description: Welcome to a new version of my site. This move enables me to organize my writing in one place (see Medium and Substack Posts) and lower the friction of posting small notes - primarily for myself, but some may be useful for others. In the spirit of being a Recurser, here’s my small contribution to learning generously. Notes with a * prefix = resource collection (may/may not include any notes)

item.title: Raytracer
item.description: During my first Recurse Center retreat in the fall of 2021, I worked on code craftsmanship and experimented with a variety of software engineering concepts. One tangent led me to writing a ray tracing engine. GPUs rule In the course of exploring photorealistic image generation for movies and games, I discovered that the practical execution of algorithms which simulate realistic (physics-based) illumination is made possible by phenomenal advances in dedicated hardware, supported by machine learning.

item.title: *Medium and Substack (old) posts
item.description: In addition to research publications, I have a small collection of prior publicly-shared works on Medium and Substack. A few posts from each: Medium: msyvr Picture perfect: AI + medical imaging “Leave me in peace, Wizard.”: Notes on James Mickens’ talk at USENIX Security ‘18 Seeing withing: Magical imaging Substack: gaming aging Mainstreaming longevity: scaling biohacking Hedging bets on healthier aging

item.title: Mickens Usenix 2018
item.description: James Mickens on the value of skepticism Notes from James Mickens’ talk at USENIX Security ‘18. If you haven’t seen James’ talk and have an hour to view his actual keynote, please do yourself a favor and just go see his talk. It’s entertaining, educational, and thought provoking. Absolutely not to be missed - the most fun you’ll have while thinking about cybersecurity, machine learning, and computing more generally. Case in point, a fun still from his talk…
